an4.162:1.1: “Bhikkhus, there are four kinds of practice.
an4.162:1.5: pleasant practice with slow insight, and
an4.162:2.1: And what is the unpleasant practice with slow insight?
an4.162:2.2: It is when someone is by nature acutely given to passion, and often experiences the pain and displeasure born of passion.
an4.162:2.3: They are by nature acutely given to aversion, and often experience the pain and displeasure born of aversion.
an4.162:2.4: They are by nature acutely given to muddledness, and often experience the pain and displeasure born of muddledness.
an4.162:2.5: These five faculties manifest in them weakly:
an4.162:2.6: faith, effort, remembrance, composure, and understanding.
an4.162:2.7: Because of this, they only slowly come into proximity of the destruction of the influxes.
an4.162:2.8: This is called the unpleasant practice with slow insight.
an4.162:3.1: And what is the unpleasant practice with swift insight?
an4.162:3.2: It is when someone is by nature acutely given to passion, and often experiences the pain and displeasure born of passion.
an4.162:3.3: They are by nature acutely given to aversion, and often experience the pain and displeasure born of aversion.
an4.162:3.4: They are by nature acutely given to muddledness, and often experience the pain and displeasure born of muddledness.
an4.162:3.5: And these five faculties manifest in them strongly:
an4.162:3.6: faith, effort, remembrance, composure, and understanding.
an4.162:3.7: Because of this, they swiftly come into proximity of the destruction of the influxes.
an4.162:3.8: This is called the unpleasant practice with swift insight.
an4.162:4.1: And what is pleasant practice with slow insight?
an4.162:4.2: It is when someone is by nature not acutely given to passion, and does not often experience the pain and displeasure born of passion.
an4.162:4.3: They are by nature not acutely given to aversion, and do not often experience the pain and displeasure born of aversion.
an4.162:4.4: They are by nature not acutely given to muddledness, and do not often experience the pain and displeasure born of muddledness.
an4.162:4.5: These five faculties manifest in them weakly:
an4.162:4.6: faith, effort, remembrance, composure, and understanding.
an4.162:4.7: Because of this, they only slowly come into proximity of the destruction of the influxes.
an4.162:4.8: This is called the pleasant practice with slow insight.
an4.162:5.1: And what is the pleasant practice with swift insight?
an4.162:5.2: It is when someone is by nature not acutely given to passion, and does not often experience the pain and displeasure born of passion.
an4.162:5.3: They are by nature not acutely given to aversion, and do not often experience the pain and displeasure born of aversion.
an4.162:5.4: They are by nature not acutely given to muddledness, and do not often experience the pain and displeasure born of muddledness.
an4.162:5.5: These five faculties manifest in them strongly:
an4.162:5.6: faith, effort, remembrance, composure, and understanding.
an4.162:5.7: Because of this, they swiftly come into proximity of the destruction of the influxes.
an4.162:5.8: This is called the pleasant practice with swift insight.
an4.162:5.9: These are the four kinds of practice.”
